content.content:

Netflix’s hit drama is the latest showcase for Ato Essandoh ’95, veteran of _Jason Bourne_, ‘Blue Bloods,’ ‘Chicago Med,’ and more
By **Beth Saulnier**
These days, Ato Essandoh ’95 is famous enough that almost nobody thinks he was murdered by Leonardo DiCaprio anymore.
_Um … what’s that again?_
To clarify: about a decade ago, the  had a small but pivotal role in the Quentin Tarantino drama _Django Unchained_, playing an enslaved man named D’Artagnan whose vicious owner (DiCaprio) punishes him for escaping by having him ripped to pieces by attack dogs.
In the years after the film came out, an Internet meme persisted that Essandoh’s on-screen death was real. As the rumor went: in service of his art, he’d agreed to be killed on camera.
!
Essandoh faces danger on the sci-fi show “Altered Carbon.” _(Netflix)_
“A friend sent me the link, and I thought it was the dumbest thing I’d ever seen,” Essandoh recalls with a laugh. “But as I was about to click away, I saw it had like 500 comments. ‘That’s against the law! They should throw Quentin Tarantino in jail!’ And I thought, ‘These people believe this!’”
So Essandoh decided to have some fun with it. He started tweeting responses from the afterlife, including the news that one of his neighbors in heaven was Jimi Hendrix...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This site serves as an alumni network for Cornell University. While it may contain information on alumni achievements or notable events, it is not a dedicated news source. The credibility of claims related to specific news events would depend on whether they directly cite reliable sources.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence explicitly addresses the hoax surrounding Ato Essandoh's supposed death after the film's release and recounts his reaction humorously. It's a strong confirmation that the claim of him being killed during filming is false.

Query1.title: Ato Essandoh, Bourne Again - Interview Magazine
Query1.snippet: Feb 19, 2016 ... According to Internet trolls, Ato Essandoh died four years ago at the hands of Leonardo DiCaprio while filming Django Unchained. Essandoh ...

content.content:
ATO ESSANDOH IN NEW YORK, FEBRUARY 2016. PHOTOS: . STYLING: /BRIDGE ARTISTS. GROOMING: YUKIKO FOR ORIBE HAIR CARE AT WM ARTIST MANAGEMENT.
According to Internet trolls, Ato Essandoh died four years ago at the hands of Leonardo DiCaprio while filming _Django Unchained_. Essandoh played a slave named D’Artagnan and someone started a rumor that he had sacrificed his life to make the scene more realistic. “My friend tweeted it at me, and I was like, ‘What is this? This is stupid.’ But then I looked at the 500 comments, ‘Leonardo DiCaprio is an awful person for killing Ato Essandoh!’ So I started tweeting from up in the afterlife,” the actor says with a laugh. “I had a lot of fun with it.”
Essandoh did not grow up with Hollywood aspirations. Rather, the New Rochelle, New York native studied biochemical engineering at Cornell. “My professors from Cornell are amazed,” he says. “My professor, who was my mentor, now it’s his big tag line when he’s introducing new students to Cornell’s curriculum. ‘Here are all the things you can do: You can go work for a biotech company, an oil company, do research, or get chewed up by dogs in _Django Unchained_,’ and everybody laughs.” Then,...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Founded by Andy Warhol, Interview Magazine has a history of celebrity interviews and cultural commentary. While it can be informative, it often features subjective content rather than hard news, which may not always verify claims robustly. It can be a useful source for celebrity information but should be cross-referenced with more traditional news outlets.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence confirms that the claim about Ato Essandoh dying during filming is a rumor that started on the internet and that he humorously engaged with it. This directly refutes the claim and is very relevant to understanding the truth behind the rumors regarding his death.

Query1.title: Ato Essandoh On 'The Code', 'Django Unchained' & Will Smith ...
Query1.snippet: Apr 16, 2019 ... ... was making jokes all the time on set," said Essandoh. I'm up in a tree, there's dog and I'm about to die and he's making a joke every time.

content.content:
[Content truncated]... the only actors in show business with a chemical engineering degree from Cornell University.
After appearing in shows such as "Elementary" and "Blue Bloods," Essandoh is back on CBS as Major Trey Ferry in the network's new drama "The Code." The show tells the story of U.S. Marines in uniform and in the courtroom. The Cornell grad is excited to be home on CBS.
"I used to do a lot with this show called 'Elementary' and Craig Sweeny was one of the writers on the show," said Essandoh in an interview with CBS Local. "Unbeknownst to me, he had gone on to create 'The Code.' When I got the audition it was a really great script, but I was worried about doing a procedural and a case of the week. I did a conference call with him and explained what the scope of the show was and he sold me within the first five minutes."
 by  on 
In addition to his role on "The Code," Essandoh has worked on several films such as "Django Unchained" and "Blood Diamond." The co-star of the new CBS drama will never forget his experience on Django because he got to work with Quentin Tarantino and did his own stunts.
"It was weirdly fun. One of the things I remember is when I went on my audition and finally met Quentin Tarantino, he was making jokes all the time on set," said Essandoh. I'm up in a tree, there's dog and I'm about to die and he's making a joke every time. He also wants me to not be focused on one aspect. He wants to see the full human being and this guy shoots every single angle. My character is a slave that gets caught and eaten by the dogs. It's a really horrible scene, but I love dogs, so I did the stunt. These dogs were 150 lbs. When you feel that dog bite, it's insane."
Another memorable moment from Essandoh's career was working alongside Will Smith in "Hitch." Essandoh learned very quickly just how big of a star Smith is.
"We have this scene in a cab where it's just me and Will," said Essandoh. "He is what everyone wants Will Smith to be. He is legitimately an awesome person. I got to interact with him a little bit and this guy is incredible. I'm sitting in the cab with him as we're going down Broadway and the car stops. It just...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: CBS News is a reputable news organization known for its journalistic standards and fact-checking processes. While it may provide credible coverage of events, it is important to look for specific articles about claims such as Ato Essandoh's reported death. Overall, CBS has a history of reliability, but like all media outlets, it can occasionally have lapses.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence cites Ato Essandoh discussing his experience on set, including a serious scene with dogs, and refers to him doing stunts. While it suggests he was present during filming, it does not directly address the claim of him being killed, but it does allude to the absurdity of the rumor.

Query2.title: How Ato Essandoh of 'The Diplomat' Spends His Sundays - The ...
Query2.snippet: May 7, 2023 ... In the 1990s, Ato Essandoh was planning to become a professor when a girlfriend at Cornell University, where he graduated with a bachelor's ...

content.content:
Advertisement
You have a preview view of this article while we are checking your access. When we have confirmed access, the full article content will load.
The actor has analog tastes, like listening to records and walking in the park. He will sneak in a little “Flight Simulator,” though.
!
Ato Essandoh at Legacy Dumbo, a record store in Brooklyn. “As much as a technophile as I am," the actor said, “I love to listen to actual records.”Credit...Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
In the 1990s, Ato Essandoh was planning to become a professor when a girlfriend at Cornell University, where he graduated with a bachelor’s degree in chemical engineering, dared him to audition for a play.
He never looked back, landing parts in movies from “Garden State” to “Django Unchained” and TV shows including “Blue Bloods” and “Girls.” Now the 50-year-old actor is currently starring opposite Keri Russell in the new Netflix series “.”
Mr. Essandoh lives alone in a two-bedroom apartment in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. He is not looking for roommates. “Living with other people is not a problem, but I like being the captain of my own space,” he said. “I like walking around in my underwear.”
Image
“I’m going to say this right now: Peck’s is the best pastry shop and coffee shop on the planet,” Mr. Essandoh said.Credit...Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
**GO-TO** I drag myself out of bed weirdly early. I don’t want to be around anybody right away, but I’ll sort of emerge from my lair, and the first place I go is , across the street. I’m going to say this right now: Peck’s is the best pastry shop and coffee shop on the planet....[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The New York Times is one of the most respected newspapers globally, known for its rigorous journalistic standards and fact-checking processes. It has a long history of investigative reporting and generally provides accurate and reliable information. However, some might critique its perceived biases, which is why it does not receive a perfect score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This piece provides context about Ato Essandoh's career and mentions that he's still active in the industry, indicating that he was not killed during or after the filming of 'Django Unchained'. While it does not explicitly state that he is alive, the implied continuity of his career is a strong indication against the claim.

It confirms that Essandoh is alive and provides context around the false rumor, making it highly relevant to the claim.

Query2.title: In Netflix's 'Away,' Ato Essandoh is an African-British-Jewish ...
Query2.snippet: Sep 10, 2020 ... Kwesi prays in Hebrew when the going gets tough on the spacecraft — it happens often during the crew's multi-year journey — and early on he ...

content.content:
I accept the JTA Privacy Policy.
By submitting the above I agree to the privacy policy and terms of use of JTA.org
(JTA) — Ato Essandoh isn’t Jewish, or British, or an astronaut — but he plays an African-British-Jewish astronaut on TV.
In Netflix’s new hit drama “Away,” about an international crew of astronauts who set out on a critical near-future mission to Mars, Essandoh plays botanist Kwesi Weisberg-Annan, an orphan who is raised by a white Jewish mother and an African Jewish father in England after his parents are killed in his native Africa. Kwesi prays in Hebrew when the going gets tough on the spacecraft — it happens often during the crew’s multi-year journey — and early on he notes that he brought aboard a Torah.
Luckily for Essandoh, he already had the Jewish side of his role down, as he put it, since he had previously portrayed a Black Jewish character — Dr. Isidore Latham on “Chicago Med.”
“The British part was the problem — I was like, now I have to learn a dialect! But I said, ‘OK, I have the Jewish thing down,’” he said with a laugh on the phone from his home in Brooklyn.
He also had a head start on learning Jewish culture from his childhood in upstate New York, where he said he was surrounded by Jewish friends and brought up by parents who encouraged him to explore different histories and belief systems — ranging from Norse mythology to the New Testament to the fairy tale stories of West Africa.
The role of Kwesi is just the latest in a wide-ranging career that kicked into high gear after a supporting part as Natalie Portman’s adopted brother in Zach Braff’s 2004 indie hit “Garden State.” Essandoh, now 48, spoke with the Jewish Telegraphic Agency about Black-Jewish representation on screen, his favorite Jewish prayer and his family’s obsession with bagels.
This interview was edited and condensed...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Jewish Telegraphic Agency (JTA) is a credible source of news regarding Jewish affairs and Israeli issues. Known for covering relevant news and analysis, it typically adheres to journalistic standards. That said, as with any organization, bias can influence reporting, hence the score.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: While this discusses Essandoh's role in another project, it does not address the claim or provide sufficient information about his status in relation to the filming of 'Django Unchained'.

QA.Question: What evidence confirms or refutes Ato Essandoh's claim of being killed during 'Django Unchained' filming?
QA.Answer: Ato Essandoh's claim of being killed during the filming of "Django Unchained" is clearly refuted by available evidence. 1. **Essandoh's Current Activity**: Ato Essandoh is alive and active in his career; as recently as May 2023, he was featured in a New York Times article discussing his life and career in the arts, where he was noted to be starring in new projects (Query 2_evidence 1). This directly contradicts any claim that he died during the filming of "Django Unchained," as he remains involved in the entertainment industry. 2. **Clarification of the Rumor**: There has been a persistent Internet rumor suggesting that Essandoh died during the filming due to a scene involving dogs; however, he himself addressed this misconception. He explained that he found it amusing that people believed the rumor, and he even joked about it on social media, tweeting from the "afterlife" as a form of satire (Query 1_evidence 1 and Query 1_evidence 2). This demonstrates that the rumor is entirely fictional and the result of misinformation. 3. **Nature of the Role**: Ato Essandoh played a character named D’Artagnan in "Django Unchained," who unfortunately meets a tragic end in the film. This portrayal has led to misconceptions due to the drama of the scene, but it is essential to emphasize that on-screen deaths do not equate to the actual death of the actor (Query 1_evidence 1). In conclusion, the combination of Ato Essandoh's continued presence and activity in the entertainment industry, coupled with his own acknowledgment of the absurdity of the rumor, provides strong evidence that he was not killed during the filming of "Django Unchained."
